case_title: COMMISSIONER OF INCOME-TAX, ASSAM vs TEZPUR AUTOMOBILE
complaint_summary: The Commissioner of Income-Tax alleged that Tezpur Automobile concealed income and furnished inaccurate particulars in its return for the assessment year 1961-62.
investigation_summary: The Income-Tax Officer scrutinized accounts and added back Rs. 35,532 from the expenses account, Rs. 41,407 from tyres and tubes account, and Rs. 8,500 as cash credits from undisclosed sources. The penalty proceedings were initiated under section 271(1)(c) of the Income-tax Act, 1961.

judgment_summary.decision: The Income-tax authority was justified in starting penalty proceedings under section 271 of the Income-tax Act, 1961.
judgment_summary.costs: Each party to bear its own costs

Decision_or_verdict: Penalty proceedings under section 271(1)(c) of the Income-tax Act, 1961, were justified.

legal_arguments.assessee_contention: Penalty proceedings should fall under section 28(1)(c) of the Income-tax Act, 1922, as the assessment was initiated under the old Act.
legal_arguments.department_contention: Penalty proceedings under section 271(1) of the Income-tax Act, 1961, are valid for assessments completed after April 1, 1962, as per section 297(2)(g).

citations: S. C. Magavi, Haveri v. Commissioner of Income-tax (1967) 64 ITR 409
Shakti Offset Works v. Inspecting Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax (1967) 64 ITR 637
Kishanlal v. Commissioner of Income-tax (1967) 64 ITR 285
C. A. Abraham v. Income-tax Officer, Kottayam (1964) 41 ITR 425
Kalawati Devi Harlalka v. Commissioner of Income-tax (1967) 66 ITR 680
Miss Saroj Nayudu v. Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax (1967) 64 ITR 637
Third Income-tax Officer, Mangalore v. M. Damodar Bhat (1969) 71 ITR 806
T. S. Baliah v. T. S. Rangachari (1969) 72 ITR 787
key_issues: Applicability of section 271(1)(c) of Income-tax Act, 1961 for assessments initiated under the old Act.
Interpretation of transitional provisions under section 297(2)(g).
key_question: Whether, on the facts and circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was right in holding that no penalty under section 271(1) of the Income-tax Act, 1961, can be levied in respect of any assessment for the assessment year 1961-62 or earlier year which is completed on or after 1st April 1962, in spite of the provisions of section 297(2)(g) of the Income-tax Act, 1961?

assessment_details.income_assessed: Rs. 35,532 added to expenses account, Rs. 41,407 added to tyres and tubes account, Rs. 8,500 added as cash credits

final_adjustments.cash_credits: Retained Rs. 4,500 adopting peak credit method

maxims.Interpretation of fiscal statutes: Fiscal statutes should be interpreted in favor of the taxpayer unless explicitly stated otherwise.

legal_terms.Penalty: A financial punishment imposed for violation of tax laws.
legal_terms.Assessment: The determination of tax liability based on income returns.

words_and_phrases.Concealment of income: Failure to disclose income in tax returns.
words_and_phrases.Undisclosed sources: Income or credits not properly accounted for.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around the applicability of penalty provisions under the Income-tax Act, 1961 for assessments initiated under the repealed Income-tax Act, 1922. Conflicting judicial precedents were analyzed, and the court upheld the validity of section 271(1)(c) for penalties post-April 1, 1962.
